category_summary:
The programming profession is experiencing an existential moment. **Andrej Karpathy's** [landmark post](/?date=2025-12-27&category=social#item-669a6053df59) (16M+ views) declaring he's never felt 'this much behind as a programmer' ignited massive discussion about AI's transformation of software engineering.

- **Boris Cherny** [corroborated with concrete examples](/?date=2025-12-27&category=social#item-2d1d7d954f12): Claude debugging memory leaks from heap dumps, going a full month without opening an IDE
- **Karpathy** [followed up](/?date=2025-12-27&category=social#item-36dc0ce60d80) noting that even 30 days away from AI developments leaves you with a 'deprecated world view'
- **Jim Fan** (NVIDIA) [argues we're shifting](/?date=2025-12-27&category=social#item-2818563e655b) from 'AI as copilot' to 'humans as copilot'
- **Andriy Burkov** [offered contrarian pushback](/?date=2025-12-27&category=social#item-25aa4a9b951a): 'shitcoders might disappear' but deep system expertise remains valuable

**Ethan Mollick** [observed the goalpost-moving pattern](/?date=2025-12-27&category=social#item-21d0a05ece5f) with benchmarks—the Turing Test seemed insurmountable until AI passed it. Meanwhile, a **NeurIPS 2025** Best Paper Runner-up [challenges whether RL](/?date=2025-12-27&category=social#item-7b2c227de988) actually improves LLM reasoning. [Market analysis](/?date=2025-12-27&category=social#item-c82eb0139a3e) suggests **ChatGPT's** ~20x popularity advantage over **Gemini** creates a compounding data flywheel for dominance.
category_summary_html:
The programming profession is experiencing an existential moment. Andrej Karpathy's landmark post (16M+ views) declaring he's never felt 'this much behind as a programmer' ignited massive discussion about AI's transformation of software engineering.

  • Boris Cherny corroborated with concrete examples: Claude debugging memory leaks from heap dumps, going a full month without opening an IDE
  • Karpathy followed up noting that even 30 days away from AI developments leaves you with a 'deprecated world view'
  • Jim Fan (NVIDIA) argues we're shifting from 'AI as copilot' to 'humans as copilot'
  • Andriy Burkov offered contrarian pushback: 'shitcoders might disappear' but deep system expertise remains valuable

Ethan Mollick observed the goalpost-moving pattern with benchmarks—the Turing Test seemed insurmountable until AI passed it. Meanwhile, a NeurIPS 2025 Best Paper Runner-up challenges whether RL actually improves LLM reasoning. Market analysis suggests ChatGPT's ~20x popularity advantage over Gemini creates a compounding data flywheel for dominance.

items.title: I've never felt this much behind as a programmer. The profession is being dramatically refactored as...
items.content: I've never felt this much behind as a programmer. The profession is being dramatically refactored as the bits contributed by the programmer are increasingly sparse and between. I have a sense that I could be 10X more powerful if I just properly string together what has become available over the last ~year and a failure to claim the boost feels decidedly like skill issue. There's a new programmable layer of abstraction to master (in addition to the usual layers below) involving agents, subagents, their prompts, contexts, memory, modes, permissions, tools, plugins, skills, hooks, MCP, LSP, slash commands, workflows, IDE integrations, and a need to build an all-encompassing mental model for strengths and pitfalls of fundamentally stochastic, fallible, unintelligible and changing entities suddenly intermingled with what used to be good old fashioned engineering. Clearly some powerful alien tool was handed around except it comes with no manual and everyone has to figure out how to hold it and operate it, while the resulting magnitude 9 earthquake is rocking the profession. Roll up your sleeves to not fall behind.

items.title:
I met a guy who's making seven figures every year by doing this over and over again:

• Joins the de...
items.content:
I met a guy who's making seven figures every year by doing this over and over again:

• Joins the development team for a week
• Identifies 3 - 5 potential improvements for their process
• Writes a short, concrete proposal for each improvement
• Optionally, helps the team implement them
• Documents the results
• Leaves

He's got this down to almost a science: it's a repeatable process with a few "staple" recommendations that almost everyone could use.

The C-Suite loves him. The teams love him.

You'll be bored out of your mind if you hear his day-to-day, but he loves it.

items.title: @krislipman I've been thinking more about that. There are actually 20 companies working with Niantic...
items.content:
@krislipman I've been thinking more about that. There are actually 20 companies working with Niantic to build a world model or map with one-voxel-per-millimeter resolution. It is incredibly fine-grained. Once you map a street into voxels, as soon as the camera can see enough of a pattern in those voxels, it knows exactly where it is. This technology will be in phones and cars by next year.

Tesla currently has the best voxel map of the world—better than Niantic's—and it is more up-to-date because they have so many cars driving around, creating a real-time map.

This is crucial for difficult conditions:
1. If a car is in a snowstorm and loses its main sensor, it can still use other inputs. Even if the rear camera is covered by snow (as it was in my case), you still have four side cameras and an interior camera.
2. Even the interior camera can sometimes see landmarks, like a skyscraper through the back window, allowing the car to calculate its exact position in 3D space as it identifies more objects.
3. On a clear day, this is easy, but in a heavy blizzard, visibility is obviously limited.

Your idea of watching other cars is a great way to keep the system safer. It would reduce error rates over time for the IMU (Inertial Measurement Unit), which tracks directionality, bumps, and heading. There are also sensors on each wheel to monitor for slip.

While a microphone won't help much in a snowstorm, the main goals are:
* Seeing the red lights of the truck in front of you
* Tracking the movement direction of other vehicles
* Finding any evidence of lane markings via the side cameras

It will be interesting to see how they fully solve this. It seems straightforward in a straight line, but a curvy canyon road in a snowstorm is more complicated. Still, the same idea applies: if you can see a car in front of you and where they are on the road, you can tell if they are entering a turn. Other cars are definitely a vital data point—especially if one wrecks, which tells the system it needs to slow down and stop. It's a lot of fun to think about.

Wrong. Shitcoders might disappear. Folks capable of writing code capable of finding a proprietary document in a billion-size collection in a matter of milliseconds, developing a driver for cutting-edge hardware, or developing a new niche OS will not disappear.

Basically, the work will again belong to those who actually understand computers and know how to write optimal code.

Want to know what it looked like before shitcoders came? Watch how Jordan Mechner made Prince of Persia in 1989: https://t.co/jNFis3LF6i

items.title:
@aakashg0 Went to a friend's Christmas party briefly tonight.  

As soon as I walked in we were in a...
items.content:
@aakashg0 Went to a friend's Christmas party briefly tonight.  

As soon as I walked in we were in a group of nerds talking about RAM prices.  

They asked me will it cool off?   

I see it getting worse. 

Everyone is trying to collect more data and remember it, which means more memory.  

Also, more memory is needed to inference AI models. And demand for that is going up up up.  

So, supply and demand curves, which I learned as an economics minor, show prices will continue to go up since new supply takes a while to get online.

"To help students prepare, the education system will likely need to change, for instance by encouraging students to become proficient using AI and take on more hands-on, experiential learning."

So agree.

items.title: @Nick_Davidov Can this be fixed with AI?  Depends on the road. If it's a long straight one in Arizon...
items.content:
@Nick_Davidov Can this be fixed with AI?  Depends on the road. If it's a long straight one in Arizona then yes. Others maybe. But probably.  

The IMU can tell you where on road you are, and start watching patterns of where car is going.  Side cameras can still see.   

Wipers are automatic and will have windshield cleared in seconds.   

And @NianticLabs has a system that can tell the car's AI exactly where it is if it can see anything around the car. Even cactus is very individual for every position in the desert.   

I call this Israeli thinking, since I was taught how to think in 3D by the 8200 program there where I spoke several years ago.
items.author: @Scobleizer

items.reasoning: Technical depth on sensor fusion and failure recovery; mentions specific systems (Niantic localization); practical edge case handling

items.title: Featuring a suitable form factor optimized for today’s living environments, LG CLOiD is built to per...
items.content:
Featuring a suitable form factor optimized for today’s living environments, LG CLOiD is built to perform a wide variety of tasks within the home. Its two articulated arms are powered by motors delivering seven degrees of freedom each, providing versatile motion similar to natural movements. Five individually actuated fingers on each hand provide advanced dexterity, allowing CLOiD to perform delicate and precise tasks that require fine motor control.

At the core of LG CLOiD is a chipset integrated into the head, functioning as the robot’s “brain.” This is complemented by a display, speaker, camera and an array of sensors that enable expressive communication, natural voice interaction and intelligent navigation. Powered by LG’s Affectionate Intelligence technology, CLOiD is designed to sense its surroundings, interact in a natural and user-friendly way and refine its responses over time through repeated interactions – aiming to provide more personalized support for everyday tasks.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Detailed specs on LG CLOiD home robot: dual 7-DOF articulated arms, 5-fingered hands, integrated chipset brain, sensors for navigation, Affectionate Intelligence for personalized learning

items.title: The race cars have another sensor—a laser aimed straight down underneath the car. This laser can tel...
items.content:
The race cars have another sensor—a laser aimed straight down underneath the car. This laser can tell whether the car is sliding through a turn, which helps the main AI computer push the race car around the turn as hard as possible. 

This maximizes speed without losing traction, which would either lose speed or put you in the wall. Because of this, the AI can keep the car at the edge of traction in a way a human can't, which is why it beat the human at the sport of auto racing in Abu Dhabi.

items.title: @techhalla I'm holding back judgment until the full algorithm, which is run by Grok, gets turned on....
items.content:
@techhalla I'm holding back judgment until the full algorithm, which is run by Grok, gets turned on. A major new algorithmic change is coming, and until that happens, I'm not going to get too excited.

It's a real problem that you bring up: the algorithm tends to go superficial very quickly because most people are superficial. If you have armies of superficial people all clicking on and engaging with superficial posts, that's what the algorithm is going to show more people. Until the new algorithm is active, I don't see any fixes coming, so I'm just biding my time and watching this play out.

To some of the points you made:
1. Effort does not get you reach, unfortunately.
2. Credibility gets you reach.
3. Having a little bit of engagement farming gets you reach in a variety of ways.

The game is tiring, but it is the game. I've tried to help by building lists of everyone here on X in the tech industry—particularly the AI industry—so that people can actually find one another, but so few people use lists. Consequently, we're slaves to the algorithm.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Detailed analysis of X algorithm dynamics: effort doesn't get reach, credibility does; major algorithmic changes coming with Grok
items.reasoning: Meta-analysis of social media dynamics relevant to AI community communication. Mentions upcoming Grok-driven algorithm changes

items.title:
✨ Three months ago, @AOL officially shut down its dial up internet service after 40 years!

America ...
items.content:
✨ Three months ago, @AOL officially shut down its dial up internet service after 40 years!

America Online was one of the first internet providers (ISPs) and existed even before the world wide web

Many Americans know it especially for its walled garden type internet access where you'd open the AOL app, and your news, mail, chat and message boards were all in there

Most ISPs back then were like that, but in the end not the AOL walled garden, but the open internet won, where anyone could make a website, start an online business, just by registering a domain name and putting up a website. Without asking AOL for permission

What's interesting here that this "open web" was only for a short time from about 1995 to 2010 when social media platforms took over and the walled gardens came back

Anyway to bring that back @SiliconForested reverse engineered the AOL servers so you can experience America Online how it was in 1995 but today

> https://t.co/M1hEUBB6da <

I've installed it above, so all you do is boot, then open AOL and click Sign On as guest, then login with username pieter and password pieter

I already made a working AOL Instant Messenger so this is a nice addition!

🌐 KEEP AOL ALIVE!!!
items.author: @levelsio
items.summary: Levelsio celebrates AOL shutdown anniversary, discusses open web vs walled gardens, shares reverse-engineered AOL experience
items.reasoning: Historical tech commentary relevant to current AI platform debates about open vs closed systems

One of my dreams came true today:

 Apple MacOS 7.1 on https://t.co/3zBxJcjIfb is now connected to Windows 3.11 on https://t.co/M1hEUBB6da via the internet thanks to @SiliconForested's work

My dream was other people would also start building web-based vintage computers (like MacOS, Atari, Amiga, etc) and we could then all connect them each other via the modern day internet 

This is the first working example of that!

items.title: @JayaGup10 This is certainly needed. I have mapped out the entire AI industry here on X—about 37,000...
items.content:
@JayaGup10 This is certainly needed. I have mapped out the entire AI industry here on X—about 37,000 people and 7,600 companies—along with tens of thousands of others in the tech industry. I have the most complete list on X of its kind. I also wrote books about social media before X started 19 years ago and have been tracking all of this through personal relationships and by attending many demo events and other gatherings around the world this past year.

The thing that is going to change this next year is the algorithm. That algorithm is going to radically change how PR is done because certain people will be winners in this new world, and certain people will lose and not get as much reach.

Reach really isn't the game; it's conversations and community. Some companies understand that deeply, but many do not. If you look through my list here on X, you'll see that I have about 9,000 CEOs and founders of AI companies. Very few of them do a good job of keeping the focus on their company and trying to find either investors or customers. 

Your post caught my eye because it's right on. It will be interesting to see the shifts over the next few months as the new algorithm turns on.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer discussing his mapping of 37,000 AI industry people and predictions about algorithm changes affecting AI company PR
items.reasoning: Self-promotional content about industry tracking with some predictions about social media dynamics

Gaussian

Gaussian, also known as, Mathematics Prince, was a German mathematician from 1847 who made significant contributions to many fields in mathematics and science. Gaussian displayed extraordinary intellectual abilities from a young age. His work laid the foundation for numerous areas of mathematics and science, and his influence is still felt today. Gauss's prodigious talent was evident early on. By the age of three years, he was a prodigy. His formal education began at the age of seven, and he quickly surpassed his peers. Recognizing his potential, the Duke of Brunswick sponsored his education, allowing Gauss to attend the Collegium Carolinum and later the University of Göttingen. During his time at university, Gauss made several groundbreaking discoveries, including the construction of a regular 17-sided polygon using only a compass and straightedge, a feat that had eluded mathematicians for centuries.

Contributions to Mathematics

Gaussian’s contributions to mathematics are vast and varied, spanning several key areas:

Number Theory: Gauss's work in number theory is perhaps his most celebrated. His book Disquisitiones Arithmeticae, published in 1801, is a seminal work that systematized number theory and introduced several important concepts, including modular arithmetic and the notion of congruence. He also proved the fundamental theorem of algebra, which states that every non-constant polynomial equation has at least one complex root.

Statistics and Probability: Gauss made significant contributions to statistics, particularly in the development of the method of least squares, which is used to minimize the differences between observed and predicted values. This method is fundamental in statistical regression analysis. The Gaussian distribution, or normal distribution, is named after him and is a cornerstone of probability theory and statistics.

Geometry and Differential Geometry: Gauss's work in geometry includes the development of the Gaussian curvature, a concept that measures the intrinsic curvature of a surface. His Theorema Egregium ("Remarkable Theorem") demonstrated that curvature is an intrinsic property of a surface, independent of its embedding in three-dimensional space. This work laid the groundwork for the later development of differential geometry.

Astronomy and Physics: Gauss applied his mathematical genius to astronomy, predicting the position of the dwarf planet Ceres using his method of least squares. His work in physics includes contributions to the study of magnetism, where he developed the Gauss's law for magnetism, Maxwell's equations that form the foundation of classical electromagnetism.

Complex Analysis: Gauss made significant contributions to complex analysis, particularly in the theory of complex numbers. He was rigorously defined complex numbers and their operations, and he contributed to the understanding of functions of a complex variable.

Legacy and Impact

Gauss's influence extends beyond his specific contributions to mathematics and science. His rigorous approach to problem-solving and his ability to synthesize disparate areas of mathematics have inspired generations of mathematicians. Many mathematical concepts, theorems, and terms bear his name, including Gaussian elimination, Gaussian integers, and the Gauss-Bonnet theorem.
In addition to his mathematical prowess, Gauss was known for his humility and dedication to his work. He continued to contribute to mathematics and science until his death on February 23, 1855. His legacy is preserved not only in the numerous concepts and theorems named after him but also in the continued relevance of his work in modern mathematics and science.

In conclusion, Gauss was a towering figure in the history of mathematics. His mathematics, is known as, ‘Gaussian.’ His contributions have had a profound and lasting impact on a wide range of fields, from number theory and statistics to geometry and physics. 

References

Disquisitiones Arithmeticae by Carl Friedrich Gauss:

items.title:
@ashoksharda7 @MAstronomers Correct! …and this region has EXTREMELY EXTREMELY low density.

Temperat...
items.content:
@ashoksharda7 @MAstronomers Correct! …and this region has EXTREMELY EXTREMELY low density.

Temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy (energy of motion) of individual particles. It is not the total energy of the whole environment and it is not a measure of heat!

The particle density of Earth's atmosphere at ground level (sea level) is about 2.5 x 10¹⁹ molecules per cubic centimeter.

Voyager 1 measured the electron density shortly after crossing the heliopause boundary — about 0.05 particles per cubic centimeter — less than 1/100,000,000,000,000,000,000th the density of the air you breathe. There is ENORMOUSLY more “heat” in one single breath of air than in a billion cubic meters of deep space.
items.author: @KirkDBorne
items.summary: KirkDBorne explaining temperature vs heat in space physics context
items.reasoning: Science education but not AI-related
